titleStmt.title: Holographic Video Display of Time-Series Volumetric Medical Data

analytic.title: Holographic Video Display of Time-Series Volumetric Medical Data

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

keywords.term: I.3.3 [Computer Graphics]: Picture/Image Generation -Viewing Algorithms electro-holography

abstract.p: We describe an animated electro-holographic visualization of brain lesions due to the progression of multiple sclerosis. A research case study is used which documents the expression of visible brain lesions in a series of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) volumes collected over the interval of one year. Some of the salient information resident within this data is described, and the motivation for using a dynamic spatial display to explore its spatial and temporal characteristics is stated. We provide a brief overview of spatial displays in medical imaging applications, and then describe our experimental visualization pipeline, from the processing of MRI datasets, through model construction, computer graphic rendering, and hologram encoding. The utility, strengths and shortcomings of the electro-holographic visualization are described and future improvements are suggested.

div.p: 1 Spatio-temporal study of MS Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a disease affecting approximately 1 in every 1000 people in the United States. People with MS suffer from a variety of symptoms such as problems of vision and gait, weakness or unpleasant sensations in arms and legs, and urinary incontinence. The disease typically manifests itself in people in their 20s and 30s, and progresses over time and in an unpredictable manner that varies from patient to patient.

Focal MRI visible brain lesions are the hallmark of MS and other inflammatory diseases, strokes, neoplastic tumors, and a multitude of other pathologies; all present on magnetic resonance images as regions of abnormal intensity with characteristic temporal and spatial distribution [Guttmann et al. 1995, Guttmann et al. 1998]. These MRI abnormalities can be identified by image analysis algorithms [Kikinis et al. 1999, Warfield et al. 1995, Wells et al. 1996, Wei et al. 2002, and their volumes can be measured. Resulting segmentations of focal lesions can be visualized to provide the clinician and researcher with a picture of a disease's spatio-temporal expression. The adequate assessment of the spatio-temporal distribution of brain lesions is important to understanding the link between relapsing and remitting bouts of cognitive, motor and other disabilities of neurological origin, and the waxing and waning nature of MS lesions in the brain [Kikinis et al. 1999, Hohol et al. 1997.

We rely upon visualization tools to display lesions in clear and comprehensible relationship to anatomical structures of the brain (such as the ventricles and vasculature) which may be vectors of disease mediators like viruses, noxious chemicals, or immunecompetent cells targeting the patient's own brain cells. The visualization tools we use most frequently display complicated three-dimensional (3D) information on a 2D display, providing motion and pictorial cues to disambiguate important spatial relationships and to indicate temporal changes. From these displays, clinicians and researchers infer the relative position, orientation and shape of relevant scene features, their relationship to each other, and their behavior over time.

By engaging binocular vision, less conventional 3D displays might more effectively represent shape and layout of such scenes, and may be particularly informative when displayed features of interest have complicated shapes or are statistically similar to the surrounding field. Such displays range from stereoscopic systems that require the use of special glasses, head worn displays (HWDs) which "immerse" an observer into the 3D scene, and autostereoscopic (including holographic) displays which require no special viewing aids to see scene depth and parallax.

In order to investigate the usefulness of 3D technology for reconstructing time-varying lesions in spatial relation to other brain structures, we experimented with a visualization pipeline that culminates in an electro-holographic display. Such displays are still experimental; but as their update rate and image quality improve, we expect that electro-holographic systems will play a growing role in visualization for medical applications. Since holographic video technology is still in its infancy, we began this work expecting to sacrifice both color output and some image quality in exchange for moving, free-standing spatial images. Our goal was to construct and demonstrate this pipeline, and then to evaluate its current efficacy and future potential for visualizing the spatio-temporal expression of MS in patients.

In this paper, we begin by presenting a selection of examples of commercially available and experimental 3D displays which have recently been used to present static, dynamic or multi-channel volumetric medical data. We then describe our visualization pipeline from MRI data processing, through model construction, and then concentrate particularly on parallax view rendering, and hologram encoding. Finally, we present and discuss the resulting holographic animation, and provide conclusions and suggestions for future work.

div.head: Spatial displays for medicine
div.p: Though they have long held application interest, stereoscopic and other 3D displays are only intermittently used in medical visualization. Among the more conventional and familiar forms of stereoscopic display are: anaglyphic images viewed with redgreen or red-blue glasses; time-multiplexed images viewed with LCD shutter glasses; right-and left-eye views delivered through HWDs; and static printed stereo pairs viewed with stereoscopes.

While commercially available and somewhat popular, these displays still have many drawbacks. They require a viewer, who may already wear corrective lenses, to use extra and sometimes cumbersome eyewear to receive the stereo effect, and typically they functionally disjoin convergence and accommodation which normally operate in conjunction -potentially causing eye strain and related discomfort. Sometimes used to deliver scene parallax information to a moving observer, viewer-tracking technologies remain vulnerable to tracker noise and lag, which can interrupt the important link between perception of self-motion and observed optical flow.

Less often encountered and still largely experimental are autostereoscopic displays: integral lens, parallax barrier, and projection displays, volumetric displays, holograms, holographic stereograms and electro-holographic systems (see [Halle 1997] for a review). These require no special viewing aids for an observer to see the 3D image they present, and thus allow simultaneous and uncompromised viewing of the surrounding physical environment along with the data being displayed. Most autostereoscopic displays spatially multiplex many parallax views of a scene simultaneously. So, for a viewer consuming the projected 3D image, accommodation and convergence may operate more naturally, and apparently continuous parallax of a spatially-stable scene is available within a prescribed viewing zone. These displays are often expensive to produce, may require specialized procedures to capture or generate input views, many are large, not portable and in prototype form, and many have image quality lower than that of conventional computer displays.

In general, the benefit 3D displays may bring to clinical and medical research applications remains unquantified and controversial; more or less so depending on the type of display and its technological embodiment. However, since medical visualization is one of the primary applications that designers of 3D displays envision for their technology, experiments with medical data have been demonstrated on many autostereoscopic systems; here we describe a brief selection of recent and notable examples.

div.head: Some recent examples for medicine
div.p: The Center for Advanced Technology at New York University has been developing an autostereoscopic display based on the raster barrier technique [Perlin et al. 2000, Perlin et al. 2001. This system tracks a moving observer's position, renders the appropriate views and delivers them through a dynamically reconfigurable parallax barrier situated in front of the pixel plane.

An observer can view the 3D scene within a 20° viewing angle, and from a distance of 0.3 to 1.5m. This system has been used to display three-dimensional medical datasets; its presentation of pseudocolored model data describing the abdomen is shown in Figure 1. The display itself physically resembles a conventional workstation, and the images it produces have high spatial resolution, are rich with pictorial cues to depth and layout, and show few artifacts. Some remaining challenges in this and related technological embodiments are the improvement of system frame rate, image brightness, and viewer tracking performance. Two interesting commercially-available volumetric displays have been used to present 3D medical models and volumetric scan data. The Perspecta 3D system from Actuality Systems Inc. (Burlington, MA) presents a 360° horizontal and 270° vertical view of scenes which may contain 100 million voxels. The addressable image volume is approximately 250mm in diameter, and images within this space are swept out by a rotating projection screen [Favalora et al. 2002]. The resulting images are spatially stable, fairly bright, full-color, and can be inspected by many observers simultaneously. The display as shown in Figure 2 presents the anatomy of the pelvis of a female patient, with bone and organs displayed slightly smaller than life-size, and with the partial transparency characteristic of volumetric displays. Voxgrams from Voxel Inc. (Provo, UT) are holograms that display static medical CT, MRI or other volumetric data on a Voxbox, which is very similar to lightboxes clinicians already use.

These displays holographically encode slices from a medical scan on a sheet of photosensitive material. The resulting holograms reconstruct the slices spatially, each positioned to match the metrics of acquisition, and each semi-transparent to prevent any occlusion within the volume. The volume of information resident within all individual slices is thus simultaneously made available for the researcher or clinician to view and assess.

The inability of volumetric displays to report occlusion relationships is worthy of note here. Occlusion is a powerful cue to scene layout, and usually carries the percept even in the presence of conflicting information. Given their potency, a display incapable of reporting occlusion relationships suffers a notable handicap. In many diagnostic applications however, occlusions may hide information of potential interest, especially when parallax is limited. As a result, the semi-transparent and nonoccluding nature of volumetric displays may be appropriate for some medical diagnostics.

Optically recorded holographic stereograms provide a different way to display optically captured or computer graphically rendered views of medical models and datasets. Under either monochromatic or broad spectrum illumination, holographic stereograms reconstruct an entire sweep of parallax views at once, displaying apparently continuous parallax within their viewzone. An early example, shown in Figure 3, was generated at the MIT Media Laboratory's Spatial Imaging Group. The figure shows a two-channel holographic stereogram. Rendered parallax views showing two different aspects of the data (anatomical and dosimetric) were generated and incorporated into the holographic stereogram to be reconstructed in different parts of the viewzone. An observer moving from viewzone-left would see leftward parallax of the anatomy model, and rightward parallax of the dosimetry model was visible within viewzone-right. Many holographic stereogram displays are horizontal-parallaxonly (HPO) and as such, present changing scene parallax only as a viewer moves from side to side. When an observer moves vertically within the viewzone, the scene geometry appears to shear around the image plane. For many application domains, the resulting apparent deformation is unnoticeable; however, in medical applications, this shearing deformation could lead to misinterpretations of the data. To remedy this effect, full-parallax holographic stereograms can be used to present geometricallycorrect information throughout the entire viewzone.

Excellent embodiments of this kind of holographic stereogram have been produced by Zebra Imaging, Inc. (Austin, TX). Their holograms are produced in a single optical step by tiling exposures of small hologram elements called hogels [Klug et al. 1993] on photosensitive material. In one example, a five-channel full-parallax holographic stereogram was produced to compare the brain of a healthy patient with that of a patient diagnosed with advanced Alzheimer's disease. Two holographic stereograms created with the full suite of rendered views are shown in Figure 4. Their output is full-color and bright, metrically correct and visible over a large vertical and horizontal field of view. These examples show that autostereoscopic displays are becoming viable in many forms, and some are now commercially available.

It is no longer difficult to envision these kinds of displays on-site in our laboratories or hospitals in the coming years. Still more distantly practicable are electro-holographic displays, promising output that combines both the remarkable realism and effectively continuous parallax of holographic displays, and the interactivity and dynamic output of electronic displays. All systems reported at the time of this writing (see [St-Hilaire et al. 1990, St-Hilaire et al. 1994, Yoshikawa et al. 2000, Hyunhee-Choi et al. 2002, Slinger et al. 2001] for a selection) still face substantial technological hurdles, but collaborations like the one described in this paper may help to guide technology development forward to better meet domain-specific needs.

div.head: Case study and modeling
div.p: In this work, we employed a series of MR images which had been acquired over a one-year interval from the brain of a 38 year-old male patient diagnosed with relapsing-remitting MS. The patient was scanned 24 times: on a weekly basis for the first eight weeks, biweekly for the next 16 weeks, monthly for the remainder of the year, and on intermittent occasions when disease activity was observed. During each scan session, contiguous axial 3mm slices with an in-plane voxel size of 0.94mm × 0.94mm were acquired covering the entire brain (for acquisition details see [Kikinis et al. 1999).

We selected nine time-points from the resulting sequence of volumetric scans to encode into an animation. The pathway used to process each MRI volume began with image analysis and processing tools that co-registered and segmented the data, and constructed 3D models. These models were processed and rendered, and the resulting images were encoded into frames of a holographic animation. The visualization pipeline is shown in Figure 5, and its stages are described in more detail in the following sections.

div.head: Processing and segmentation
div.p: In this work, we used model data that was generated previously for earlier studies involving the same patient MRI volumes [Kikinis et al. 1999. For those studies, models were created from the output of a two-step processing approach. In the first step, the intracranial cavity (ICC) was identified for each volume in the time-series [Kikinis et al. 1992].

In the second step, all serial MRI volumes were spatially coregistered to a reference time-point. This registration was performed as an automated series of translations and rotations using ICC contours from individual time-points as corresponding features. This process results in a common registered ICC for all MRI volumes in the time-series.

After registration, segmentation into four tissue classes (white matter, grey matter, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and white matter lesions) was achieved using an Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm [Wells et al. 1995, Wells et al. 1996. In this process, a segmenter, based on statistical models of intensity properties and inhomogeneities in imaged tissues, estimates tissue classes and a correction factor for signal intensity at each pixel within a volume. The segmentation operation produces labeled/binary tissue classifications for each image pixel in every volume in the time-series.

The EM segmentation was further improved by correcting partial voluming effects, a source of classification error in algorithms relying solely on signal intensity characteristics. In particular, misclassifications are likely for image pixels near the brain surface that contain both brain tissue and either bone or CSF. These pixels often present an intensity similar to white matter lesions, and may yield false-positive lesions in the segmentation results. To correct for partial voluming effects, an algorithm based on morphological operators and connectivity principles was applied [Sera 1992].

Finally, a connected-component labeling process was used to automatically identify different lesions and produce the final registered, segmented serial data sets [Metcalf et al. 1992]. The output label maps, specified for each slice in every MRI volume, identified the ventricles and described the size and position of each lesion at every time-point. From these label maps, surface models of the ventricles, and lesions at every time-point were generated using the marching cubes algorithm [Lorensen and Cline 1987]. The number of triangles contained within this representation was then decimated to improve rendering time.

div.head: 3D Slicer
div.p: We reformatted the description of these models to be compatible with 3D Slicer [www.slicer.org] (sometimes also called Slicer), an open source visualization and analysis software system currently being developed jointly by the MIT Artificial Intelligence Lab and the Surgical Planning Lab at Brigham & Women's Hospital. 3D Slicer provides capabilities for automatic registration, semiautomatic segmentation, generation of 3D surface models, 3D visualization, and quantitative analysis of various medical scans. In this work, 3D Slicer was used to import ventricle and brain lesion models, smooth their surfaces, transform them into view, assign material and lighting properties to the resulting scene and to render a sweep of parallax views for each of the nine selected time-points. Its parallax rendering geometry was configured to generate suitable input for the hologram encoding process.

div.head: View generation for spatial display
div.p: Distortion-free reconstruction on any spatial display requires careful design of the view rendering or capture geometry to match that of the display's projection [Halle 1997]. To determine the correct configuration, we began with the projection geometry of the display to be used in this work (the MIT second-generation holographic video display, or holovideo [St-Hilaire et al. 1990, St-Hilaire et al. 1994); the display's projection parameters were determined both by holovideo's display geometry and by the computational method used to encode the holograms (both will be described in more detail). The following set of guidelines was employed to ensure a good correspondence between parallax view rendering and the target holographic horizontal-parallax-only (HPO) reconstruction:

The distance D between the camera and rendering window should correspond within a scale factor S to the orthogonal distance between the HPO hologram viewzone and holographically-projected image plane (in our case D=590mm with S=1);

The distance P that the camera travels to capture parallax should correspond within the scale factor S to the hologram's viewzone width (P=381mm); As is evident in the final guideline listed, computed holograms offer very high parallax projection resolution -often more than necessary to reconstruct our data. We chose to economize by capturing fewer views over the same parallax range, and allowing each to project through a larger angle. Thus, the capture geometry was configured with camera spacing c = 2.7mm, yielding 142 views across the entire viewzone. Consequently, each captured view was effectively spread through an angle of about 0.26°, which is an integer multiple M=80 of the hologram's minimum projective increment p .

A properly-configured shearing and recentering camera geometry, which maintains forward-facing view normal vectors as shown in Figure 6, was implemented within the 3D Slicer. Parallax views were rendered for each of the nine selected time-points in the sequence, converted to 8-bit greyscale images. According to our rendering guidelines, the pixels in each image were required to have an aspect ratio of p w /p h =0.502 in order to match the sample spacing in holovideo's projected image plane. However, 3D Slicer's underlying rendering engine currently permits only square pixels. Consequently, each parallax image was rendered with 192×144 square pixels and stretched to create images with 383×144 non-square pixels suitable for hologram encoding. For every time-point, these stretched parallax views were stored in consecutive order to a file as an image stack. Each image stack was used as input to the hologram encoding process. Figure 7 shows a selection of rendered parallax views from the stacks representing three different time-points in the study.

div.head: Holographic video
div.p: Holographic systems use diffractive patterns as a means of angularly redirecting input light, much as other systems use lenslet arrays or reflective optics to spatially multiplex view information. In an electro-holographic display, the prescription for redirecting input light is contained in a computer generated hologram; changing and updating that diffractive pattern can change the display's projective behavior and also modify the information it projects.

The MIT second-generation holovideo display [St-Hilaire et al. 1994], used in this work, presents 150 x 57.5 x 150mm monochromatic red (Helium-Neon laser illuminated) HPO images, visible within a 30 degree view zone. As an HPO system, holovideo offers holographic resolution horizontally (256K samples per line) and video resolution vertically (144 hologram lines); and at 8 bits per sample, computed holograms contain a 36MB diffractive (or fringe) pattern. The display is refreshed at a rate of 30 frames per second, and the current image update rate is about 2.5 full frames per second. An observer, positioned a distance D=600mm away from the hologram plane can see a flicker-free 3D image floating in space, either static or changing over time.

Holovideo supports the most important cues to depth and layout: stereopsis, motion parallax, occlusion, and many pictorial and physiological cues to depth. The resulting image can also exhibit various visible artifacts such as: horizontal or vertical gaps or vertically-varying brightness in the output plane; dark fringes located off the output plane; variable brightness throughout the viewzone; and laser speckle. Such artifacts may arise from various sources including some computation methods, potential optical misalignment and extraneous problems with the display's electronic and computational subsystems.

The sharpness, resolution, and pictorial richness of the 3D images displayed on this system also substantially depends on the method used to compute the holograms [Plesniak and Halle (under review), Underkoffler 1997, Lucente 1996, Plesniak 2003]. A new technique called reconfigurable image surface (RIS) or reconfigurable image plane (RIP) hologram computing [Plesniak and Halle (under review)] was used in this work, since it offers excellent image quality for stereogram-type images and its parameters can be adjusted to meet scene sampling requirements.

div.head: RIP holograms
div.p: RIP holograms project one (or more) series of parallax views of a 3D scene through one (or more) holographically-reconstructed image planes. Image planes are comprised of a collection of primitives, such as spherical wave emitters (points), and are located some distance away from the hologram plane. Each primitive is specified in the hologram by an instance of the same pre-computed and filtered interference pattern. In hologram reconstruction, these primitives on the image plane act as individual "projector-pixels" (called holo-pixels), and are used to relay the parallax view pixel information to different locations in the viewzone (as shown in Figure 8). This spatial multiplexing is accomplished by modulating each holo-pixel's interference pattern with a "slice" through the parallax view stack at a corresponding holo-pixel location. If the geometry of capture and projection correspond, then a single holo-pixel directs view pixel information back out along the direction of original capture. As a result, when an observer's eyes sweep through the viewzone, the projected image plane displays to each eye the parallax views captured at corresponding locations. Figure 8: Generating view-multiplexing "holo-pixels".

div.head: Diffractive projection
div.p: The projector fringe used in this work is a one-dimensional pattern which, when placed within a hologram line, focuses input illumination to a point 10mm away. This projector fringe f(x) was derived from the interference of an inclined plane wave and a spherical wave whose source was 10mm from the hologram plane.
The following real-valued expression [Lucente 1996] can be used to describe the signal-bearing part of this interference pattern at samples across the HPO hologram:
div.formula: ref x x r x f sin ) ( 2 cos ) ((1)
div.p: where the wavelength =633nm for Helium-Neon laser light, r(x) describes the radius of curvature of the spherical wave at sample values across the hologram plane, and ref =-15° describes the angle of the plane wave's incline. This pattern is computed between the hologram samples at which its spatial frequency evaluates to zero and to a value below the Nyquist limit (approximately 800 cy/mm in the holovideo system). These values specify that, for an illumination angle of ill =-15°, the maximum diffraction (output) angle is out =+14°. Thus, each holo-pixel can project scene parallax information through a total angle of 29°. To prevent visible diffractive artifacts generated by its edges, the fringe is windowed by a Blackman filter.

When illuminated by holovideo's reconstructing plane wave, a single filtered projector fringe will focus the input illumination to a point 10mm in front of the hologram. Positioning a projector fringe within any hologram line causes the point to reconstruct at the hologram line's vertical height. Horizontally translating the projector fringe across the hologram moves the reconstructed point along with it. From the viewzone, an observer will see the holo-point positioned in front of the hologram, and appearing uniformly bright throughout a 29° angle of view.

div.head: Modulating with view information
div.p: To modulate the holo-point's brightness throughout its projective angle, its projector fringe is weighted (as indicated in Figure 8) by a "slice" through the parallax view stack at a corresponding view pixel location (shown in Figure 9). Since a projector fringe's output angle is limited, it may deliver view information to only part of the viewzone; consequently, only view pixels from an appropriate subset of parallax views are used to modulate its samples. In our example, view pixels from 113 of 142 total parallax views are used to modulate a projector fringe. A RIP hologram is assembled by positioning and superposing many different view-modulated instances of the projector-fringe within the final computer-generated pattern. Their reconstructed images will collectively form a densely-populated plane of holopixels (whose positions have been slightly spatially perturbed to interrupt their regularity, thereby reducing diffraction artifacts).
Once an entire pattern is assembled in this "multiply-andaccumulate" fashion, it must be normalized to a range of 0-255 to produce a 36MB hologram with 8 bits per sample.

In this manner, a RIP hologram was computed on a 250MHz SGI Onyx for each selected time-point using each of the nine parallax view stacks. Each hologram took 273 seconds to compute and normalize; and each reconstructed a 3D image of the scene straddling the single projected image plane. The projected image plane was 144 hologram lines high and 383 non-square holopixels across, and described an area 75.4mm wide and 56.5mm high. For each time-point, an observer moving through the viewzone could see the appropriate parallax views of the ventricle and brain lesion data straddling the projected image plane ( Figure 10). All nine holograms could be displayed as individual frames for static inspection, or were pre-loaded together and played palindromically in a movie loop.

div.head: Results and evaluation
div.p: The holograms for each of the nine time-points reconstructed shaded model surfaces in high contrast, with crisp focus and good metric precision (Figures 11 and 12). The images were bright and maintained their overall brightness throughout much of the viewzone, becoming slightly dimmer nearer its extremes. The image was free of diffraction artifacts, appeared dimensional and deep (about 40mm), and could be seen animating over time at a rate of approximately 2.5 frames per second. Though the quality of the 3D images was quite good, the presence of artifacts, rooted in either holovideo's computational or RF subsystems, were somewhat distracting. In particular, the failure of two optical channels (resulting in periodically missing hologram lines) presented as dark horizontal gaps across the final images, and represented omitted image information. Throughout the animation, the ventricles were seen to remain fixed in space, stretching from about 10mm in front of the image plane to approximately 30mm behind it. Around the ventricles, brain lesions were seen to grow and shrink over time; one lesion located at the top-left-rear of the reconstructed image volume expressed most dramatically over the time-points we visualized. The depth, layout and changing shape of all scene features were clearly represented, though the dark gaps in the image broke continuity of shape throughout the image and could fragment or entirely eliminate smaller features.

The following technological improvements -perhaps prioritized according to the order given -could be recommended to improve the effectiveness of holovideo for medical data visualization. First and most importantly, the ability to interactively transform the spatial image and drive the animation forward and back through time is critical. Pre-recorded movie loops may be appropriate after the data has been explored and the intervals and angles of greatest interest are determined. Next, while the spatial display provides a very good presentation of the depth and layout of brain lesions relative to ventricles, having a wider angle of view (permitting greater head movement and multiple simultaneous viewers) is very important. Also providing vertical parallax would allow viewers to have greater freedom of movement without encountering distortion. More obvious goals would be to provide better greyscale resolution to strengthen shape from shading inferences, to add color to help label and distinguish features, and of course to eliminate as many artifacts as possible from the spatial output images.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: This work demonstrated a visualization pipeline culminating in an experimental electro-holographic display. We tested this pipeline using time-series volumetric medical data. Surface models, generated from nine time-points within the patient dataset, were computer graphically rendered and encoded into holographic stereograms using RIP hologram computing. Resulting static and animated holographic images were presented for inspection and evaluation.

The final display showed scene depth and layout very well, and indicated the shape of ventricles and brain lesions. Despite visible artifacts, the output image quality was encouraging, and suggestions were provided to further improve the system's viability for medical imaging applications. This study strongly supports the continued development of real-time holographic video systems and their ongoing evaluation as visualization tools for time-series volumetric medical data.
